ai_explanation.Enhance_understanding: Enhance your understanding with our AI-driven report explanations.

consent_request.paragraph: By using this feature, you agree that OpenAI is a subprocessor and may process the data you’ve chosen to submit. Sentry makes no guarantees as to the accuracy of the feature’s AI-generated recommendation.

ai_explanation.popover_text: This AI-generated solution offers an ergonomic risk assessment based on posture and movement analysis. Accuracy not guaranteed.

assessments.takt_time_description: Takt Time is the target cycle time for tasks, helping scale movements and static times to hourly rates for accurate assessment.

privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_1: We understand that you may sometimes wish to delete your account and associated data from our platform. Below are the steps to initiate this process:
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_10: If you are a Non-Admin user:
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_11: Contact your organisation’s admin to request account and data deletion.
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_12: Wergonic follows your organisation’s data management policies.
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_2: If you are an organization admin and wish to delete your account and associated data, please follow these steps:
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_4: In the subject line, please write "Data Deletion Request".
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_5: In the body of the email, include the following information:
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_6: Your account details (such as username, email address).
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_7: Specify the data you want to delete (e.g., user profiles, project information).
privacyAndDataDeletionPolicyPage.text_9: Once we receive your request, our team will process it promptly and ensure that your account and data are deleted in accordance with our privacy policies.  Thank you for using Wergonic.

categories.examples: Contact details, such as real name, alias, postal address, telephone or mobile contact number, unique personal identifier, online identifier, Internet Protocol address, email address, and account name

categories.category: B. Personal information categories listed in the California Customer Records statute
categories.examples: Name, contact information, education, employment, employment history, and financial information

categories.category: C. Protected classification characteristics under California or federal law

categories.examples: Transaction information, purchase history, financial details, and payment information

categories.category: F. Internet or other similar network activity
categories.examples: Browsing history, search history, online behaviour, interest data, and interactions with our and other websites, applications, systems, and advertisements

categories.category: H. Audio, electronic, visual, thermal, olfactory, or similar information
categories.examples: Images and audio, video or call recordings created in connection with our business activities
Business contact details in order to provide you our Services at a business level or job title, work history, and professional qualifications if you apply for a job with us

categories.category: K. Inferences drawn from other personal information
categories.examples: Inferences drawn from any of the collected personal information listed above to create a profile or summary about, for example, an individual’s preferences and characteristics

categories_table.description: We have collected the following categories of personal information in the past twelve (12) months:
categories_table.title: What categories of personal information do we collect?

privacyPolicyPage.intro: This privacy notice for Wergonic AB ('Company', 'we', 'us', or 'our'), describes how and why we might collect, store, use, and/or share ('process') your information when you use our services ('Services'), such as when you:

post_table_content.additional_information: We may also collect other personal information outside of these categories through instances where you interact with us in person, online, by phone or mail in the context of:
additional_information_list: Receiving help through our customer support channels
Participation in customer surveys or contests
Facilitation in the delivery of our Services and to respond to your inquiries

content: If you have questions or comments about this notice, you may contact our Data Protection Officer (DPO), Farhad Aftahi, by email at support@wergonic.com, or by post to:
contact_information.title: 12. HOW CAN YOU CONTACT US ABOUT THIS NOTICE?

content: We may disclose your personal information with our service providers pursuant to a written contract between us and each service provider. Each service provider is a for-profit entity that processes the information on our behalf.

We may use your personal information for our own business purposes, such as for undertaking internal research for technological development and demonstration. This is not considered to be 'selling' of your personal information.

Wergonic AB has not disclosed or sold any personal information to third parties for a business or commercial purpose in the preceding twelve (12) months. Wergonic AB will not sell personal information in the future belonging to website visitors, users and other consumers.
info_sharing_with_others.title: Will your information be shared with anyone else?

information_use_share.authorized_agent: If you are using an authorised agent to exercise your right to opt out we may deny a request if the authorised agent does not submit proof that they have been validly authorised to act on your behalf.
information_use_share.contact_info: You may contact us by email at info@wergonic.com, or by referring to the contact details at the bottom of this document.
information_use_share.content: More information about our data collection and sharing practices can be found in this privacy notice.
information_use_share.title: How do we use and share your personal information?

other_privacy_rights.contact_info: To exercise these rights, you can contact us by email at info@wergonic.com, or by referring to the contact details at the bottom of this document. If you have a complaint about how we handle your data, we would like to hear from you.
list: You may object to the processing of your personal information.
You may request correction of your personal data if it is incorrect or no longer relevant, or ask to restrict the processing of the information.

You can designate an authorised agent to make a request under the CCPA on your behalf. We may deny a request from an authorised agent that does not submit proof that they have been validly authorized to act on your behalf in accordance with the CCPA.

You may request to opt out from further selling of your personal information to third parties. Upon receiving an opt-out request, we will act upon the request as soon as feasibly possible, but no later than fifteen (15) days from the date of the request submission.
other_privacy_rights.title: Other privacy rights

review_rights.content: Based on the applicable laws of your country, you may have the right to request access to the personal information we collect from you, change that information, or delete it. To request to review, update, or delete your personal information, please submit a request form by clicking here.
review_rights.title: 13. HOW CAN YOU REVIEW, UPDATE, OR DELETE THE DATA WE COLLECT FROM YOU?

rights_with_respect_to_data.content: Right to request deletion of the data — Request to delete
rights_with_respect_to_data.delete_right: You can ask for the deletion of your personal information. If you ask us to delete your personal information, we will respect your request and delete your personal information, subject to certain exceptions provided by law, such as (but not limited to) the necessity to exercise by another consumer of his or her right to free speech, our compliance requirements resulting from a legal obligation, or any processing that may be required to protect against illegal activities.

details: whether we collect and use your personal information;
the categories of personal information that we collect;
the purposes for which the collected personal information is used;
whether we sell your personal information to third parties;
the categories of personal information that we sold or disclosed for a business purpose;
the categories of third parties to whom the personal information was sold or disclosed for a business purpose; and
the business or commercial purpose for collecting or selling personal information.
info_requests_right.title: Right to be informed — Request to know

rights_with_respect_to_data.non_discrimination: We will not discriminate against you if you exercise your privacy rights.
rights_with_respect_to_data.title: Your rights with respect to your personal data

update_policy.content: In Short: Yes, we will update this notice as necessary to stay compliant with relevant laws.
update_policy.title: 11. DO WE MAKE UPDATES TO THIS NOTICE?
update_policy.update_details: We may update this privacy notice from time to time. The updated version will be indicated by an updated 'Revised' date and the updated version will be effective as soon as it is accessible. If we make material changes to this privacy notice, we may notify you either by prominently posting a notice of such changes or by directly sending you a notification. We encourage you to review this privacy notice frequently to be informed of how we are protecting your information.

verification_process.content: Upon receiving your request, we will need to verify your identity to determine you are the same person about whom we have the information in our system. These verification efforts require us to ask you to provide information so that we can match it with information you have previously provided us. For instance, depending on the type of request you submit, we may ask you to provide certain information to verify your identity or place a phone call to you. We will only use personal information provided in your request to verify your identity or authority to make the request. To the extent possible, we will avoid requesting additional information from you for the purposes of verification. If, however, we cannot verify your identity from the information already maintained by us, we may request that you provide additional information for the purposes of verifying your identity and for security or fraud-prevention purposes. We will delete such additionally provided information as soon as we finish verifying you.
verification_process.title: Verification process

privacyPolicyPage.questions: Questions or concerns? Reading this privacy notice will help you understand your privacy rights and choices. If you do not agree with our policies and practices, please do not use our Services. If you still have any questions or concerns, please contact us at info@wergonic.com.

10_california_privacy_rights.content: In Short: Yes, if you are a resident of California, you are granted specific rights regarding access to your personal information.

details.ccpa_notice:
The California Code of Regulations defines a 'resident' as:
(1) every individual who is in the State of California for other than a temporary or transitory purpose and
(2) every individual who is domiciled in the State of California who is outside the State of California for a temporary or transitory purpose
details.shine_the_light: California Civil Code Section 1798.83, also known as the 'Shine The Light' law, permits our users who are California residents to request and obtain from us, once a year and free of charge, information about categories of personal information (if any) we disclosed to third parties for direct marketing purposes.

10_california_privacy_rights.title: 10. DO CALIFORNIA RESIDENTS HAVE SPECIFIC PRIVACY RIGHTS?

1_information_collection.content: In Short: We collect personal information that you provide to us.

details.application_data: If you use our application(s), we also may collect the following information if you choose to provide us with access or permission:
details.data_requirements: All personal information that you provide to us must be true, complete, and accurate, and you must notify us of any changes to such personal information.
details.personal_information: We collect personal information that you voluntarily provide to us when you express an interest in obtaining information about us or our products and Services, when you participate in activities on the Services, or otherwise when you contact us.
sensitive_data_examples: data about a person's sex life or sexual orientation
details.sensitive_information: When necessary, with your consent or as otherwise permitted by applicable law, we process the following categories of sensitive information:

1_information_collection.title: 1. WHAT INFORMATION DO WE COLLECT?

2_information_processing.content: In Short: We process your information to provide, improve, and administer our Services, communicate with you, for security and fraud prevention, and to comply with law. We may also process your information for other purposes with your consent.

details.delivery_service: To deliver and facilitate delivery of services to the user. We may process your information to provide you with the requested service.
details.vital_interest: To save or protect an individual's vital interest. We may process your information when necessary to save or protect an individual’s vital interest, such as to prevent harm.

2_information_processing.title: 2. HOW DO WE PROCESS YOUR INFORMATION?

3_legal_bases.content: In Short: We only process your personal information when we believe it is necessary and we have a valid legal reason (i.e. legal basis) to do so under applicable law, like with your consent, to comply with laws, to provide you with services to enter into or fulfil our contractual obligations, to protect your rights, or to fulfil our legitimate business interests.

details.consent: Consent. We may process your information if you have given us permission (i.e. consent) to use your personal information for a specific purpose. You can withdraw your consent at any time.
details.contract_performance: Performance of a Contract. We may process your personal information when we believe it is necessary to fulfil our contractual obligations to you, including providing our Services or at your request prior to entering into a contract with you.
details.eu_uk_law: If you are located in the EU or UK, this section applies to you.
details.legal_obligations: Legal Obligations. We may process your information where we believe it is necessary for compliance with our legal obligations, such as to cooperate with a law enforcement body or regulatory agency, exercise or defend our legal rights, or disclose your information as evidence in litigation in which we are involved.
details.vital_interests: Vital Interests. We may process your information where we believe it is necessary to protect your vital interests or the vital interests of a third party, such as situations involving potential threats to the safety of any person.

3_legal_bases.title: 3. WHAT LEGAL BASES DO WE RELY ON TO PROCESS YOUR INFORMATION?

4_information_sharing.content: In Short: We may share information in specific situations described in this section and/or with the following third parties.

details.business_transfers: Business Transfers. We may share or transfer your information in connection with, or during negotiations of, any merger, sale of company assets, financing, or acquisition of all or a portion of our business to another company.

4_information_sharing.title: 4. WHEN AND WITH WHOM DO WE SHARE YOUR PERSONAL INFORMATION?

5_information_retention.content: In Short: We keep your information for as long as necessary to fulfil the purposes outlined in this privacy notice unless otherwise required by law.

details.deletion: When we have no ongoing legitimate business need to process your personal information, we will either delete or anonymise such information, or, if this is not possible (for example, because your personal information has been stored in backup archives), then we will securely store your personal information and isolate it from any further processing until deletion is possible.
details.retention_period: We will only keep your personal information for as long as it is necessary for the purposes set out in this privacy notice, unless a longer retention period is required or permitted by law (such as tax, accounting, or other legal requirements).

5_information_retention.title: 5. HOW LONG DO WE KEEP YOUR INFORMATION?

6_information_security.content: In Short: We aim to protect your personal information through a system of organisational and technical security measures.

details.security_measures: We have implemented appropriate and reasonable technical and organisational security measures designed to protect the security of any personal information we process. However, despite our safeguards and efforts to secure your information, no electronic transmission over the Internet or information storage technology can be guaranteed to be 100% secure.

6_information_security.title: 6. HOW DO WE KEEP YOUR INFORMATION SAFE?

7_minor_information.content: In Short: We do not knowingly collect data from or market to children under 18 years of age.

details.no_collection: We do not knowingly solicit data from or market to children under 18 years of age. By using the Services, you represent that you are at least 18 or that you are the parent or guardian of such a minor and consent to such minor dependent’s use of the Services.

7_minor_information.title: 7. DO WE COLLECT INFORMATION FROM MINORS?

8_privacy_rights.content: In Short: In some regions, such as the European Economic Area (EEA) and United Kingdom (UK), you have rights that allow you greater access to and control over your personal information.

rights_list: request access and obtain a copy of your personal information
restrict the processing of your personal information
details.withdraw_consent: Withdrawing your consent: If we are relying on your consent to process your personal information, you have the right to withdraw your consent at any time.

8_privacy_rights.title: 8. WHAT ARE YOUR PRIVACY RIGHTS?

9_dnt_controls.content: Most web browsers and some mobile operating systems and mobile applications include a Do-Not-Track ('DNT') feature or setting you can activate to signal your privacy preference not to have data about your online browsing activities monitored and collected.
9_dnt_controls.title: 9. CONTROLS FOR DO-NOT-TRACK FEATURES

summary.exercise_rights: How do you exercise your rights? The easiest way to exercise your rights is by filling out our data subject request form available here, or by contacting us. We will consider and act upon any request in accordance with applicable data protection laws.
summary.intro: This summary provides key points from our privacy notice, but you can find out more details about any of these topics by clicking the link following each key point or by using our table of contents below to find the section you are looking for.
summary.more_info: Want to learn more about what Wergonic AB does with any information we collect? Click here to review the notice in full.
summary.personal_information: What personal information do we process? When you visit, use, or navigate our Services, we may process personal information depending on how you interact with Wergonic AB and the Services, the choices you make, and the products and features you use. Click here to learn more.
summary.processing_info: How do we process your information? We process your information to provide, improve, and administer our Services, communicate with you, for security and fraud prevention, and to comply with law. We may also process your information for other purposes with your consent.
summary.security_info: How do we keep your information safe? We have organisational and technical processes and procedures in place to protect your personal information.
summary.sensitive_information: Do we process any sensitive personal information? We may process sensitive personal information when necessary with your consent or as otherwise permitted by applicable law. Click here to learn more.
summary.sharing_info: In what situations and with which parties do we share personal information? We may share information in specific situations and with specific third parties.
summary.third_party_info: Do we receive any information from third parties? We do not receive any information from third parties.
summary.title: SUMMARY OF KEY POINTS
summary.user_rights: What are your rights? Depending on where you are located geographically, the applicable privacy law may mean you have certain rights regarding your personal information.

items: 2. HOW DO WE PROCESS YOUR INFORMATION?

privacyPolicyPage.title: PRIVACY NOTICE

usage.app: Download and use our mobile application (Wergonic), or any other application of ours that links to this privacy notice
usage.other: Engage with us in other related ways, including any sales, marketing, or events
usage.website: Visit our website at http://wergonic.com, or any website of ours that links to this privacy notice

ramp_assessments.assessment_can_not_submit_form_error: Please complete the form before submittion!
ramp_assessments.calculation_backward_bending_10_degrees: Percentage of time with backward bending more than 10 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_backward_bending_5_degrees: Percentage of time with backward bending more than 5 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_elevation_angle_90_degrees: Percentage of time with elevation angle above 90 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_forward_bending_30_degrees: Percentage of time with forward bending more than 30 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_forward_bending_45_degrees: Percentage of time with forward bending more than 45 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_hand_distance_30_cm: Percentage of time with hand distance more than 30 cm from the body.
ramp_assessments.calculation_side_bending_10_degrees: Percentage of time with side bending of more than 10 degrees.
ramp_assessments.calculation_side_bending_30_degrees: Percentage of time with side bending of more than 30 degrees.
ramp_assessments.delete_multiple_assessments_warning: This action is irreversible and might lead to lost data. If you would like to continue please input the next phrase.

influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_a: a. The employee is exposed to hand-arm vibration more than 20 minutes (10 for strongly vib.)
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_a_b_info: Assess the duration (per day) that the employee is exposed to hand-arm vibrations and if the vibration emission exceeds 10 m/s2 (strongly vibrating).
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_b: b. The employee is exposed to hand-arm vibration more than 90 minutes (60 for strongly vib.)
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_c: c. Warm or cold objects are handled manually
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_c_info: Assess if warm (≥43°C) or cold objects (<10°C) are handled manually.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_d: d. The hand is used as an impact tool often or a long time
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_d_info: Assess if the hand is used as an impact tool often or a long time. “Often” means about 100 times per working day or more and “a long time” is about 30 minutes per work day or more.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_e: e. Holding hand tools weighing more than 2.3 kg for more than 30 minutes
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_e_info: Assess whether the tools weighing more than 2.3 kg are held for more than 30 minutes in total per work day.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_f: f. Holding precision tools weighing more than 0.4 kg for more than 30 minutes
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_f_info: Assess whether precision tools weighing more than 0.4 kg are held for more than 30 minutes in total per work day.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_1_title: 5.1 Influencing physical factors hand/arm - do the following occur? The times refer to "per work day".
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_a: a. The employee is exposed to whole-body vibration more than 1 hour
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_a_b_info: Assess the total time that the worker is exposed to whole-body vibrations.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_b: b. The employee is exposed to whole-body vibration for more than 6 hours
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_c: c. The visual conditions are insufficient for the task
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_c_info: Assess if the visual conditions are insufficient for the task. An inadequate visual condition (for the task) means that the visual conditions are insufficient to perform the work well from an ergonomic perspective. The reasons for this may include inappropriate lighting e.g. glare and poor contrast. Poor visual conditions may also cause awkward postures in attempts to compensate for the poor visual conditions which may increase the risk of musculoskeletal disorders and/or pain.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_d: d. The work is carried out in hot or cold temperatures or in draughty environments
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_d_info: Assess if the work occurs in cold, heat and draught.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_e: e. Standing or walking on a hard surface more than half of the work day
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_e_info: Assess if the worker stands or walks on a hard surface for more than half of the work day. This paragraph may require expert judgment where various properties of the shoe-floor interaction are combined. An example of a hard surface is concrete. Parquet floors and carpets do not generally count as hard surfaces in this case. However, the employee’s experience should be considered in the assessment. Note also that an overly soft surface may cause fatigue of the workers.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_f: f. Prolonged sedentary work without possibility to change to do the work standing up
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_f_info: Assess if the worker has prolonged sedentary work without the possibility to do the work standing up. If the worker has the possibility to change position between sitting, standing and walking regularly, then the work should not be assessed as prolonged sedentary or prolonged standing.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_g: g. Prolonged standing work without possibility to change to do the work sitting down
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_g_info: Assess if the worker has prolonged standing work without the possibility to do the work sitting down. If the worker has the possibility to change position between sitting, standing and walking regularly, then the work should not be assessed as prolonged sedentary or prolonged standing.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_h: h. Kneeling/squatting more than 30 times or more than 30 minutes
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_h_info: Assess if the work involves kneeling or squatting more than 30 times or more than 30 minutes per work day. Example: Working in a kneeling position in the morning (20 minutes) followed by 25 minutes squatting in the afternoon. Calculation: 20 + 25 minutes = 45 minutes (yellow, 2 points).
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_2_title: 5.2 Other physical factors - do following occur? The times refer to "per work day"
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_a: a. There is no possibility to influence at what pace the work is performed
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_a_info: Assess whether or not the employee can influence at which pace the work is performed. “There is no possibility to influence at what pace the work is performed” refers to e.g. if the pace is controlled by a machine or someone other than the person does the job. This means that there are few or no possibilities to vary the pace of work if needed, or to carry out the work at “their own pace”. Preferably, ask three to five employees.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_b: b. There is no possibility to influence the work setting or how the work shall be carried out
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_b_info: Assess whether or not the employee can influence how the work is carried out. “There is no possibility to influence the work setting or how the work is carried out”, refers to the decision latitude of the employee, e.g. whether the employee has participated in the planning of the work or can influence how the work is carried out. Preferably, ask three to five employees.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_c: c. It is often difficult to keep up with the work tasks
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_c_info: Assess whether it is often difficult to keep up with the work tasks.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_d: d. The employees often work rapidly in order to be able to take a longer break
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_d_info: Assess whether the employee often works rapidly in order to take a longer break.
influencing_factors_form.influencing_factors_3_title: 5.3 Work organizational and psychosocial factors - do the following occur?
influencing_factors_form.title: 5. Influencing factors

labels.30_seconds_or_less_per_10_minutes_work: 30 seconds or less per 10 minutes work
labels.90_seconds_or_more_per_10_minutes_work: 90 seconds or more per 10 minutes work
labels.varied_movements: Varied movements, movement now and then (up to 2/min)

lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text: Example 3a: An employee lifts two different types of carton during a working day. All lifts occur within normal lower arm distance and from floor level to waist height (the handle is placed about 10 cm above floor level). One carton weighs an average of 12 kg and is lifted an average of 12 times per hour per working day (which is eight hours). The other weighs 25 kg and is lifted once per working day. No other aggravating/influencing factors arise, see Figure 31. Assessment of average case: Since the heavy carton is rarely lifted, only the carton that weighs 12 kg is assessed. The frequency and weight factor is obtained from Table 1: 12 times per hour (lie in the range ”7.6 – 12 times per hour”) and 12 kg (lies in the range ”over 10 kg – 15 kg”) give frequency and weight factor 3.8.  We find from Table 2 that the working area factor for lifting from floor level within working distance (2.0) is higher than that for lifting to waist height within lower arm length (0.9), which means that a working area factor of 2.0 is selected. These two factors are entered in Table 3 in the “Factor” column and the assessment for “Risk score 1” is 7.6 and red. Assessment of worst case: Assess the lift of the 25 kg carton, which is lifted once per working day. In this case the frequency and weight factor is 5.4 and the working area factor is 2.0. When these two factors are entered in Table 3 in the column “Possible worst case Factor” “Risk score 2” of 10.8 is obtained and is therefore red.
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_1: The assessment applies only for load weights of 1 kg or more.
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_2: Assess both “the average case” and “the worst case”. The worst case may, for example, consist of a single lift of a heavy object or an object that is lifted with several aggravating factors.
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_3: Assess the weight of the load and how frequently it is lifted (Table 1).
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_4: Assess the horizontal and vertical distances at the origin and destination (or between the origin and destination). Choose the task/lift with the highest score.
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_5: Calculate the risk score (Table 3) by multiplying factors from Table 1 and 2 with possible influencing factors. Insert the risk scores for the average case (Risk score 1) and worst case (Risk score 2). The table at the bottom of the figure shows if the risk score corresponds to green, yellow or red level of risk/action level.
lifting_work_form.info_dialog_text_6: If no worst case occurs (i.e., the score from the worst case is lower than the average case), then insert the score for the average case in both risk scores 1 and 2.
lifting_work_form.lifting_work_2: Torso twisted more than 30 degrees. (see figure to the right)
lifting_work_form.lifting_work_2_info: Assess the twist (rotation) between the shoulders and the feet. This means that also knee, hip and trunk rotation is included.
lifting_work_form.lifting_work_3_info: Poor grip means that it is difficult to obtain an adequate grip for the hand and fingers, or that the grip surface is slippery or has sharp edges, or that the center of gravity is not centered, or that the content is unstable or moving, or that the grip does not otherwise meet requirements for a good grip.
lifting_work_form.lifting_work_4_info: At temperatures of more than 32° C reduce the lifting capacity even further. Requires expert assessment.
lifting_work_form.no_factor_text: If the factors below don't occur in the majority of the lifts: Click the alternative to the right
lifting_work_form.no_lifting_work_note_1: If no lifts occur: Click the box on the right.
lifting_work_form.no_lifting_work_note_2: Frequent handling of light loads (less than 1 kg) is covered in other parts of RAMP II
lifting_work_form.table_1_factor_text: Frequency and weight factor from Table 1
lifting_work_form.title: 3. Lifting work

movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_1_description: How are the movements of the arm generally?
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_1_dialog_text: Assess arm movements and recovery patterns that generally occur during the work being assessed according to the table above. Other: Make a general assessment of the arm’s working movements as they occur during a representative working day. A pause here means an opportunity for recovery for the shoulder area during work, not during breaks. The assessment refers to the arm that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state the risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk score.
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_1_title: 2.1 Movements of the arm (upper arm and lower arm)
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_2_description: Do similar movements of the wrist occur?
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_2_dialog_text: Assess the number of wrist movements per minute during a representative working day according to the table above. Other: Make a general assessment of how often writ movements generally occur during a representative working day. Similar movements means working movements that load the same bodily structure in a similar way. The assessment refers to the hand that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state the risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk scores. Example 2.2a: The hand is moved clearly upwards (extension) from the neutral position and then back. This is assessed as one movement. Example 2.2b: The hand is moved clearly upwards (extension) from the neutral position and then back. It is then moved clearly downwards (flexion) and back. This is assessed as two movements.
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_3_description: Is overhand grip (palm facing downward), wide finger grip or pinch used while lifting or holding objects weighing 0.5 kg or more?
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_3_dialog_text: Assess the number of handlings per working day of objects that weight 0.5 kg or more and that are lifted or held with an overhand grip (palm down), wide finger grip, pincer grip (see figure above) or corresponding (loaded) grip. Other: Assess the total handling in one of the group types or corresponding loaded grip. The assessment refers to the hand that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk score. Example 2.3a: During a normal working day an employee lifts 60 (1 kg) items with an overhand grip with the right hand, then 80 (1.5 kg) items with a wide finger grip with the right hand and then 200 (0.4 kg) items with a pincer grip with the right hand. The person then lifts 110 (1 kg) items with the left hand. Assessment for the right hand: 140 items (60 + 80) weighing at least 0.5 kg are lifted. This is in the range 101-200 times per day and is assessed with risk score 2, i.e. the assessment will be yellow. Assessment for the left hand: 110 items weighing at least 0.5 kg are lifted. This is in the range 101-200 times per day and is assessed with risk score 2, i.e. the assessment will be yellow. Assessment: The assessment that is higher of the right or left hand is to be chosen. Since in this case they are the same, risk score 2 is entered for one of them on the “Results” sheet in the results table.
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_4_description: Assessment of whether or not the work enables sufficient variation or breaks so that muscle group under strain are given time to recover. The variation or break has to be at least 5 seconds at a time to be eligible. Approximately, how much of the working time consists of such variation or breaks generally?
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_4_dialog_text: Assess the total time for recovery generally during the work. Then assess the total time for recovery per 10 minutes work. Assess whether the work gives the opportunity for sufficient variation or interruption so that the muscle groups that are loaded have time for recovery. Recovery must be for at least 5 consecutive seconds in order to be counted. If the consecutive time is less than 5 seconds it is not to be counted. Other: To reduce the risk of MSDs, it is considered important to have variation in the work so that the muscle groups that are stressed (mainly during static load) have the opportunity for recovery – regarding sufficient oxygen levels and that waste products can be transported away. This can be achieved by, after a period of work when mostly certain muscles are strained, working on other tasks where these muscles have little strain and can recover. For muscle recovery to occur, one can thus vary the work during a task.
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_4_title: 2.4 Shorter recovery/variation during work (mainly regarding the neck, the arms and the back)
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_5_description: Assessment of whether or not the work enables sufficient variation or breaks so that muscle group under strain are given time to recover. The variation or break has to be at least 5 minutes when total together to be eligible. Approximately, how often does such variation or breaks occur during the work generally?
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_5_dialog_text: Assess the total time for recovery generally during the work. Assess whether the work gives the opportunity for sufficient variation or interruption so that the muscle groups that are loaded have time for recovery. Add together the recovery times (that are at least 5 consecutive seconds) that occur. Thus, they do not need to be 5 consecutive minutes. Recovery means for example that the muscles that have been under load have the opportunity to recover, e.g. by using other parts of the body for a period. This means that total rest is not required. Other: To reduce the risk of MSDs, it is considered important to have variation in the work so that the muscle groups that are stressed (mainly during static load) have the opportunity for recovery – regarding sufficient oxygen levels and that waste products can be transported away. This can be achieved by, after a period of work when mostly certain muscles are strained, working on other tasks where these muscles have little strain and can recover. For muscle recovery to occur, one can thus vary the work during a task.
movements_repetition_form.movements_repetition_5_title: 2.5 Longer recovery/variation during work (not breaks, e.g. task rotation that gives sufficient recovery)
movements_repetition_form.title: 2. Work movements and repetitive work

perceived_physical_discomfort_form.info: Check whether tasks causing physical discomfort (e.g. in muscles or joints) occur during the work day. Preferably, ask five employees. If any of the employees answers “yes” to the question, the result is yellow (score 2).
perceived_physical_discomfort_form.perceived_physical_discomfort_1_a: Are there parts of the work which lead to physical discomfort (e.g. in muscles or joints) during the work day? Answer "Yes" if employee experiences such discomfort.
perceived_physical_discomfort_form.perceived_physical_discomfort_1_title: Preferably ask five people who perform this work task.
perceived_physical_discomfort_form.perceived_physical_discomfort_2_title: 7.2 If "Yes" on 7.1, which is the worst task? Preferably state answers from five employees in the table below.
perceived_physical_discomfort_form.title: 7. Perceived physical discomfort

postures_form.postures_1_description: Does a clear bending of the head forwards or to the side, or twisting to the side occur, as shown in the figures, or more?
postures_form.postures_1_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the head (neck) is in stressful postures that correspond to the figures or more. Other: Bending or inclination is from the vertical. Inclination of the head is also assessed as bending. For example, forward inclination of the head can occur when working with the upper body bent forward but a non-bent neck (see the figures below). With external loads, such as when wearing a helmet in stressful postures, should be reduced still further. Expert assessment is recommended. The assessment refers to time without support. Example  1.1a: If a person works with the head turned to the side (30°) for 20 minutes and later in the day with the head bent forward (40°) for 20 minutes, these times must be added together (20+20 minutes = 40 minutes). Give this case score 1. This score means that in this case the risk level is assessed as low and is coded green. Example 1.1b: If a person works for 20 minutes with the head turned to the side (30°) and simultaneously bent forward (40°) the time is instead assessed as 20 minutes (i.e. score 0.5, green).
postures_form.postures_1_title: 1.1 Posture of the head - forwards and to the side
postures_form.postures_2_description: Does bending of the head backwards occur, as shown in the figure, or more?
postures_form.postures_2_dialog_text: Assess the total time the head (neck) is bent backwards corresponding to the figures or more. Other: Bending is from the vertical. With external loads, such as when wearing a helmet in stressful postures should be reduced still further. Expert assessment is recommended. The assessment refers to time without support.
postures_form.postures_3_description: Does moderate bending of the upper body forwards or to the side occur, as shown in the figures, or more?
postures_form.postures_3_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the back is in a stressful posture that corresponds to the figures. Other: Bending is from the vertical. The assessment refers to time without support. Add the times in stressful postures in the same way as in Examples 1.1a and 1.1b.
postures_form.postures_4_description: Does considerable bending of the upper body forwards or to the side, twisting or bending backwards occur, as shown in the figure, or more?
postures_form.postures_4_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the back is in a stressful posture that corresponds to the figures or more. Other: Bending is from the vertical. The assessment refers to time without support. Add the times in stressful postures in the same way as in Examples 1.1a and 1.1b.
postures_form.postures_4_title: 1.4 Back posture - considerable bending and twisting
postures_form.postures_5_description: Does moderate bending of the upper body forwards or to the side occur, as shown in the figures, or more?
postures_form.postures_5_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the hand (or upper arm) is above shoulder height. Other: The question refers to loads to the elbow, shoulder and neck and focuses on load due to the upper arm position. Generally speaking, there is a connection between the positions of the upper arm and hand, e.g. if the hand is at shoulder height the upper arm is often in a stressful posture (for example flexion or abduction). The assessment refers to time without support. The assessment refers to the arm that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state the risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk score.
postures_form.postures_5_title: 1.5 Upper arm posture - hand in or above shoulder height
postures_form.postures_6_description: Is performed with the hand in or outer work area? If the hand is outside the outer work area (white area), multiply the time-points for that time by 1.5
postures_form.postures_6_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the hand (or upper arm) is outside the inner working area. If the hand is both in the outer working area and outside the outer working area, the times for these count the same (see Examples 1.6a and 1.6b). Time outside the outer working area (i.e. in neither the inner nor the outer working area) is multiplied by 1.5. Other: The assessment refers to loads to the elbow, shoulder and neck because of flexed or abducted upper arm. The assessment refers to the arm that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state the risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk score. Inner working area = approximately lower arm distance to grip (forward). The inner working area on average is approximately 33 cm for women (50th percentile) and approximately 36 cm for men (50th percentile) (see Appendix 3). Outer working area = approximately ¾ arm’s length to grip (forward). The outer working area on average is approximately 45 cm for women (50th percentile) and approximately 50 cm for men (50th percentile) (see Appendix 3). The assessment refers to time without support. Example 1.6a: An employee works for 45 minutes with the right hand in front of the body at about ¾ arm’s length. This is assessed as being in the outer working area and is assessed with risk score 2, i.e. the assessment will be yellow. Example 1.6b: An employee works for 45 minutes with the right hand in the outer working area and then for 20 minutes outside the outer working area. Calculation of duration: 45 minutes + 1.5 x 20 minutes = 45+30 = 75 minutes, which corresponds to risk score 3, i.e. the assessment will be red.
postures_form.postures_6_title: 1.6 Upper arm posture - hand in or outside the outer work area
postures_form.postures_7_description: Is work performed with clearly bent wrist, as shown in the figure, or more?
postures_form.postures_7_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which the wrist is in a stressful posture that corresponds to the figures or more. Other: Add the times in stressful postures in the same way as in Examples 1.1 a and 1.1a. The assessment refers to the hand that has the higher load. If uncertain which hand has the most load, assess both hands. Only state the risk score for the hand that is assessed as having the highest risk score, or for one of them if they are assessed as having the same risk score.
postures_form.postures_8_description: Is there a lack of space for the legs or for the feet, or is the surface unstable or sloping?
postures_form.postures_8_dialog_text: Assess the total time during which there is insufficient space for the legs or feet or the surface is unstable or sloping. Other: Examples of an unstable surface are unsteady, slippery or uneven surfaces that cause the surface to be perceived as unstable. Add the times for unfavourable conditions relating to the surface or space for the legs or feet in the same way as in Examples 1.1a och 1.1b. Foot and leg operated pedal work can be assessed here, since 1.8 is largely based on the Swedish Work Environment Authority’s AFS 2012:02 (Posture p.37).
postures_form.postures_8_title: 1.8 Leg and foot space and surface
postures_form.title: 1. Postures

pushing_and_pulling_form.if_any_worst_case_Factor_Continuous_forc: If any, worst case factor continuous force
pushing_and_pulling_form.if_any_worst_case_Factor_Initial_force: If any, worst case factor initial force
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text: Example 4a: Two people push a trolley 2 meters with both hands. The grip is good and at elbow height, there are no further influencing factors. Each pushing task takes 4 seconds to perform and is repeated on average 30 times per hour per working day (which is eight hours). The median value for initial force is 225 N, and for the continuous force 80 N. Twice a day, one of the persons also pushes the same trolley alone 12 m (”worst case”), which takes 20 seconds each time. Other conditions are the same as above (see Figure 33 for calculation). Assessment of average case: Since the pushing work takes less than 5 seconds, only the initial force is measured and assessed. The frequency and force factor is obtained from Table 4: 30 times per hour (lies in the range ”13 - 30 times per hour”) and 225 N (lies in the range”201 – 250 N)” gives the Frequency and force factor 4, This factor is entered in Table 4 in the column ”Factor initial force”. Since two people push the trolley, 0.6 must also be entered in the table factor “Two persons push/pull a load” in the same column. The assessment of “Risk score 1” is 2.4 and green. Assessment of worst case: The single pushing task that is performed by one employee is assessed here. Both initial and continuous force are measured (since 20 s > 5s) so that both columns on the far right of Table 6 are filled in. Since the distance of 12 m is in the range 9-30 m, 50 N is added to the measured continuous force, 80 N. This gives 130 N as the median value for the continuous force that is to be used as the initial value for force in Table 5. The risk scores for initial force and continuous force for the worst case are both 4, i.e. 4 is the greatest value (see the bottom of the two columns on the far right of Table 6). The assessment of “Risk score 2” is 4.0 and yellow.
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_1: The assessment applies only for forces exceeding 50 N.
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_2: Assess (measure) both “the average case” and “the worst case”. The worst case may for example consist of a single exertion of high force or handling operations with several aggravating factors.
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_3: If the object is pushed or pulled for less than 5 seconds, only assess the initial force (Table 4). If the object is pushed/pulled for 5 seconds or longer, assess both the initial (Table 4) and the continuous force (Table 5).
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_4: Calculate the risk score (Table 6) by multiplying factors from Table 4 (and possibly also Table 5) with possible influencing factors. Insert the risk scores for the average case (risk score 1) and worst case (risk score 2). The table at the bottom of the figure shows if the risk score corresponds to green, yellow or red level of risk/action level.
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_5: If both initial and continuous forces are assessed, insert the one with the highest score in the table risk score 1 (average case) and risk score 2 (worst case).
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_dialog_text_6: If no worst case occurs (i.e. the score from the worst case is lower than the average case), then insert the scores for the average case in both risk scores 1 and 2.
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_title_1: Frequency and force factor for initial force (starting force)
pushing_and_pulling_form.info_title_2: Frequency and force factor for continuous force
pushing_and_pulling_form.no_factor_text: If these factors below don't occur in the majority of the push or pull work: Click the alternative to the right.
pushing_and_pulling_form.no_pushing_and_pulling_note_1: If no pushing and pulling occur: Click the box on the right.
pushing_and_pulling_form.no_pushing_and_pulling_note_2: Make an assessment for an average case. Frequent handling of light loads (exerted forces < 50 N) is covered in other parts of RAMP II.
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_1: Pushing/pulling with one hand or sideways
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_1_info: If pushing/pulling occurs to the side using one hand, then add 2.89 points in the table (i.e. 1.7 * 1.7 = 2.89).
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_2: Gripping height is below knee height or above shoulder height
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_3: Gripping height deviates considerably from elbow height
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_4: Torso twisted more than 30° (see the figure to the right above)
pushing_and_pulling_form.pushing_and_pulling_7_info: A slippery surface means (here) that the static coefficient of friction (SCOF) is less than 0.5 between the shoe sole and the ground/floor. If the friction is less than 0.2 (“very slippery”), the ability to exercise force is further reduced. Therefore, a further increase of the multiplier is recommended based on expert judgment.
pushing_and_pulling_form.table_1_and_2_factor_text: Frequency and force factor from Table 4 and, if applicable, from Table 5
pushing_and_pulling_form.title: 4. Pushing and pulling work

ramp_assessments.results_pdf_title: Results of the RAMP II analysis

strenuous_work_form.info: Check for documented reporting (e.g. incident reports) of physically strenuous work.
strenuous_work_form.strenuous_work_1_a: Do documented reports exist of physically strenuous tasks (e.g. incident reports) when carrying out the work task?
strenuous_work_form.strenuous_work_1_title: 6.1 Documented reporting on physically strenuous work
strenuous_work_form.strenuous_work_2_title: 6.2 Type of work that has lead to reporting
strenuous_work_form.title: 6. Reports on physically strenuous work

ramp_assessments.you_are_about_to_delete_the_following_as: You are about to delete the following assessments:
ramp_assessments.you_have_to_select_at_least_one_assessme: You have to select at least one assessment

reba_assessments.activity_score_1: 1 or more body parts are held for longer than 1 minute (static)
reba_assessments.activity_score_2: Action causes rapide large range changes in postures or unstable base
reba_assessments.activity_score_3: Repeated small range actions (more than 4x per minute)
reba_assessments.arm_supported_or_person_is_leaning: Arm supported or person is leaning
reba_assessments.coupling_score_1: Well fitting handle and mid range power grip, Good
reba_assessments.coupling_score_2: Acceptable with another body part, Fair
reba_assessments.coupling_score_3: Hand hold not acceptable but possible, Poor
reba_assessments.coupling_score_4: No handles, awkward, unsafe with any body part, Unacceptable
reba_assessments.high_risk_investigate_and_implement_chan: High Risk. Investigate and Implement Change
reba_assessments.low_risk_change_may_be_needed: Low Risk. Change may be needed.
reba_assessments.medium_risk_further_investigate_change_s: Medium Risk. Further Investigate. Change soon.
reba_assessments.shock_or_rapid_build_up_of_force: Shock or rapid build up of force
reba_assessments.status_2: Low Risk. Change may be needed
reba_assessments.status_3: Medium Risk. Further investigate. Change soon
reba_assessments.status_4: High Risk. Investigate and implement change
reba_assessments.wrist_is_bent_from_midline_or_twisted: Wrist is bent from midline or twisted

rula_assessments.arm_aupported_or_person_is_leaning: Arm is supported or person is leaning
rula_assessments.either_arm_is_working_across_midline_or_: Either arm is working across midline or out to the side of body
rula_assessments.legs_and_feet_are_not_supported: Legs and feet are not supported
rula_assessments.more_than_22_lbs.or_repeated_or_shocks: More than 10 kg or repeated or shocks
rula_assessments.muscle_use_score_label: Posture mainly static (i.e. held > 1 minute), or action repeated occurs 4x per minute
rula_assessments.status_2: Further investigation, change may be needed
rula_assessments.wrist_is_at_or_near_end_of_range: Wrist is at or near end of range

add_log_dialog.textArea_label: Please enter some details to this log *
add_log_dialog.upload_log_file_failed: Something went wrong while uploading the files!

appendix.extreme_load_description: the exposure exceeds this level for only five percent of the working day, indicating the highest strain levels encountered, which are rare but critical for assessing injury risk.
appendix.median_load_description: the exposure exceeds this level for half of the working day, representing the average load experienced by the worker.
appendix.minimum_load_description: the exposure remains below this level for 90% of the working day, indicating the lowest strain.
appendix.peak_load_description: the exposure exceeds this level for ten percent of the working day, highlighting peak exertion periods during tasks.
appendix.title: Explanation of Percentiles

sessions_management.assessment_generation_message: The assessment will be automatically saved and can be easily accessed from the list of assessments.
sessions_management.constraint_2_to_4: You need to select 2 to 4 sessions
sessions_management.constraint_all_done_processing: A selected session can not be in processing state

delete_multiple_sessions.sessions_deletion_multiple_intro: You are about to delete the following sessions:
delete_multiple_sessions.sessions_deletion_multiple_permission_al: You don't have the permissions to performe this action
delete_multiple_sessions.sessions_deletion_multiple_warning: This action is irreversible and might lead to lost data. If you'd like to continue please input the next phrase.
delete_multiple_sessions.sesssions_deletion_multiple_alert: You have to select at least one session

sessions_management.ending_session_alert: Are you sure you want to terminate the session of
sessions_management.error_all_done_processing: A selected session can not be in processing state
sessions_management.error_all_have_measurements: Cannot compare sessions with 'No Measurement' status. Please select sessions with valid measurements.
sessions_management.generated_assessment_link: Access the generated {{assessmentCategory}} assessment with id {{assessmentId}} based on this session.
sessions_management.generated_mec_assessment_link: Access the generated MEC assessment based on this session.

merge_info.select_at_least_two: You must select at least 2 sessions to merge.

sessions_merge_conflict.conflicting_fields: Conflicting data fields (e.g., workers, workstation, start/end times)
sessions_merge_conflict.different_states: Sessions must be in the same state (e.g., completed or processing)
sessions_merge_conflict.different_types: Different session types or incompatible session configurations
sessions_merge_conflict.header: Sessions cannot be merged due to the following reasons:
sessions_merge_conflict.merge_criteria: Please ensure the sessions meet the merge criteria and try again.

merge_multiple_sessions.sessions_merge_multiple_alert: You must select at least two sessions to merge.
merge_multiple_sessions.sessions_merge_multiple_introduction: You are about to merge the following sessions:
merge_multiple_sessions.sessions_merge_multiple_warning: This action is irreversible and might lead to data conflicts. Please ensure the sessions meet the merge criteria before proceeding.

sessions_management.missing_limb_sensor_info_description: Some data required for this assessment is missing. It appears that the recorded session does not include data from all the necessary limbs. This may result in incomplete or missing information in your assessment.

pdf_appendix.application_in_assessment_description: This report utilized the percentile-based limits established by Arvidsson et al. (2016) to assess the duration and intensity of specific postures, such as arm elevation and trunk bending, during manual handling tasks. This facilitated the evaluation of potential MSD risks based on established thresholds.
pdf_appendix.application_in_assessment_description_2: This report utilized RAMP I, a checklist for initial screening of ergonomic risks, and RAMP II, a more in-depth analysis tool. These tools helped identify high-risk manual handling tasks in the workplace and inform recommendations for improved ergonomics.
pdf_appendix.contributions_description: This publication by Arvidsson et al. (2016) establishes evidence-based threshold levels for various physical exposures known to be linked to musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs). It provides percentile-based limits for postures and movements, aiding in the quantitative assessment of risk.
pdf_appendix.green_zone: Green Zone (Low Risk): Exposure levels fall within acceptable limits, and the likelihood of MSD risk is minimal.
pdf_appendix.importance_of_risk_zones: Importance of Risk Zones in Risk Assessment
pdf_appendix.importance_of_risk_zones_description: Categorizing risk zones plays a crucial role in prioritizing interventions. This allows for the allocation of resources effectively to address tasks with the highest potential for causing MSDs. By focusing on high-risk tasks, preventive measures can be implemented to reduce the overall risk of MSDs in the workplace.
pdf_appendix.intervention_levels_title: Intervention Levels Against Musculoskeletal Injury by Inger Arvidsson from Lund University
pdf_appendix.key_feature_1: Provides a standardized framework for evaluating manual handling activities.
pdf_appendix.key_feature_2: Utilizes a colour-coded risk classification system (green, yellow, red) to categorize risk levels, allowing for prioritized interventions.
pdf_appendix.key_feature_3: Identifies high-risk tasks and postures, guiding ergonomic improvements in the workplace.
pdf_appendix.percentile_50th_description: The 50th percentile of median load represents the typical exposure level experienced by most workers performing the task. The exposure exceeds this level in total half of the working day.
pdf_appendix.percentile_90th_description: The 90th percentile or peak load signifies the extreme exposure level that a smaller percentage of workers may experience. The exposure exceeds this level in total ten percent of the working day.
pdf_appendix.ramp_purpose_description: RAMP, developed by the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) in Sweden, is a systematic tool designed to assess and manage risks associated with manual handling tasks. It offers a structured approach for identifying and evaluating physical risk factors in the workplace.
pdf_appendix.ramp_tool_title: RAMP – Risk Management Assessment Tool for Manual Handling Proactively
pdf_appendix.red_zone: Red Zone (High Risk): Exposure levels exceed acceptable limits, indicating a high risk of MSDs. Immediate corrective actions are necessary to mitigate risk.
pdf_appendix.reference_publication_details: Arvidsson, I., Dahlqvist, C., Enquist, H., & Nordander, C. (2016). 'Intervention Levels for Assessment of Risk of Work-Related Musculoskeletal Disorders.'
pdf_appendix.references_behind_assessment_description: This appendix provides detailed explanations of the references used to develop the assessment criteria employed in this report.
pdf_appendix.references_behind_assessment_title: Appendix: References Behind the Assessment and Risk Analysis Criteria
pdf_appendix.risk_zones_classification_title: Risk Zones Classification and Understanding Percentiles
pdf_appendix.yellow_zone: Yellow Zone (Moderate Risk): Exposure levels suggest some workers may be at risk for MSDs. Preventive measures are recommended to address this risk.
